topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack(R) Carrier Grade (Beta): Installation Prerequisites

body.p: This document describes the prerequisite steps and one time setup on your KVM host required to install HPE Helion OpenStack(R) Carrier Grade in a baremetal environment.

section.title: Hardware and software requirements
section.p: Before you start, if you have not done so already, make sure your environment meets the hardware and software requirements. See the HPE Helion OpenStack(R) Support Matrix.

section.title: Preparing the baremetal systems
section.p: Perform the following tasks on each baremetal system before starting the install:

li.p: Configure the boot order with Network/PXE boot as the first option:

ul.li: For example, to set the boot order for a HPE SL390, from the iLO prompt enter set system1/bootconfig1/bootsource5 bootorder=1.
To unset, enter set system1/bootconfig1/bootsource5 bootorder=5.

li.p: Configure the BIOS:

ul.li: to the correct date and time
KVM host configured in UTC (Coordinated Universal Time)
with only one network interface enabled for PXE/network boot and any additional interfaces should have PXE/network boot disabled
to stay powered off in the event of being shutdown rather than automatically restarting

li.p: Update to the latest firmware recommended by the system vendor for all system components, including the BIOS, BMC firmware, disk controller firmware, drive firmware, network adapter firmware, and so forth.

section.title: Preparing the KVM host
section.p: The following tasks need to be performed on the KVM host, the system where the you will launch the HPE Helion OpenStack(R) Carrier Grade installation.

section.title: Install Ubuntu Server 14.04.2 LTS
section.p: The KVM host must have Ubuntu Server 14.04.2 LTS installed before performing the HPE Helion OpenStack(R) Carrier Grade installation.

section.title: Obtain a public key
section.p: On the KVM host, the user root must have a public key.

li.p: Launch a terminal and log in to your KVM host as root:
sudo su -
Use the following command to create the key. Accept the default values.
/root/.ssh/id_rsa
install the public key into the authorized keys on the KVM host:
Enter the IP address of the default network gateway on the KVM.

section.title: Configure proxy information
section.p: Before you begin your installation on the KVM host, if necessary configure the proxy information for your environment using the following steps:

li.p: Launch a terminal and log in to your KVM host as root:
Edit the /etc/environment file to add the following lines, using values specific to your environment:

codeblock.codeph: PATH="/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/games:/usr/local/games" export http_proxy=http://<web_proxy_IP>/ export https_proxy=http://<web_proxy_IP>/ export no_proxy=localhost,127.0.0.1,<your 10.x IP address>,<provider_network>

li.p: Where:

codeblock.codeph: web_proxy_IP is your web proxy IP address. provider_network is your ESX management network

li.p: Source the environments file:

section.title: Install Ubuntu packages
section.p: Before starting the installation, you must first install Ubuntu.

li.p: Run the following all in one command to install packages:

codeblock.codeph: sudo su -l -c "apt-get install -y ntp firefox gedit xrdp xfce4 qemu-kvm libvirt-bin openvswitch-switch openvswitch-common python-libvirt qemu-system-x86 libssl-dev libffi-dev git python-virtualenv python-dev virt-manager xorg gnome-core gnome-system-tools gnome-app-install vlan sudo ansible"

li.p: Add the 802.1q module to the kernel on boot. The 802.1q standard supports VLAN tagging on an ethernet network.
Reboot the server
Log out and re-login to the KVM host to activate the proxy configuration.

section.title: Configure the XRDP remote desktop display
section.p: Configure XRDP for the remote desktop connection to access the server remotely as follows.

li.p: Edit the sesman.ini file:
vi /etc/xrdp/sesman.ini
a. Update the MaxSessions=1 to MaxSessions=50.
b. Configure the system to use XRDP:
c. Save and close the file.
Restart the xrdp service:
sudo /etc/init.d/xrdp restart

section.p: If the XDRP display does not work as expected, (you see a gray screen), update the startwm.sh file:

codeblock.codeph:
vi /etc/xrdp/startwm.sh
#!/bin/sh
if [ -r /etc/default/locale ]; then . /etc/default/locale export LANG LANGUAGE fi
#. /etc/X11/Xsession . /usr/bin/startxfce4

section.p: Make sure you add a space after "." then restart XDRP:

section.title: Install and configure NTP
section.p: NTP is a networking protocol for clock synchronization between computer systems.
The HPE Helion OpenStack(R) cloud nodes must be configured as NTP clients and point to the same NTP server.

You can install NTP on the KVM host and configure it as an NTP server. Or, you can use a pre-existing NTP server that is reachable from the management network. You will also need to configure the undercloud and overcloud systems as NTP clients pointing to the NTP server you have chosen to use during the installation process.
For information on installing NTP on the KVM host, see Installing an NTP Server.

section.title: Download and unpack the installation packages
section.p: Before you begin, you must download the required HPE Helion OpenStack(R) installation package(s):

li.p: Download and extract the cg-hlm.qcow2 and VSD qcow2 files to the images folder.
Download and extract the cg-infra-playbooks.tar.gz.gpg file to the /root directory.
This will create the /root/cg directory and extract the contents into the directory.
Copy the cg-hos.tar.gz.gpg and cg-hos-dcn.tar.gz.gpg to the /root/cg/ directory.
The password to decrypt the files is cghelion.

section.p: On the KVM host, the OpenSSH server must be running and the firewall configuration should allow access to the SSH ports.
